author: {'steamid': '76561198103216424', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2561, 'last_played': 1461916667}
review:
shantae and the pirate's curse is a 2d action platformer where players assume the role of the titular character, the adorable half-genie shantae. in this game, she teams up with her rival risky boots to save the world from a looming threat, the return of the (in case you couldn't already tell from the title) master pirate, who was defeated and sealed away by the guardian genies years ago.

unlike the previous game, which takes place in just one island, meaning a single interconnected world, this game is divided into different, separated levels, with shantae exploring five islands (not including the first one, where scuttle town is located) in a more or less linear way: the level design itself is fairly linear, but the player will often need to return to previous islands, either to perform some action that will allow the story to progress, either to get some collectible that was previously inaccessible and that you can now obtain thanks to abilities that have since been acquired; this way of organizing the world, making the player move back and forth between islands, is why shantae and the pirate's curse is considered a member of the metroidvania group of games.

the collectibles mentioned in the previous paragraph are divided into two categories: 1. dark magic, in the form of tinkerbats that have now mutated thanks to it and that you will need to defeat to seal said magic inside your lamp, and 2. squid hearts, which can then be melted in groups of four and transformed into extra health by the "squidsmith". 

the aforementioned scuttle town, where the game begins and the town of which shantae is the guardian genie, will serve as a hub, to which she will often return, either to perform some necessary action (often in the form of interactions with npcs) or to acquire items and upgrades.

in each of the remaining five islands shantae will find a den of evil, a place from where the master pirate is obtaining the dark magic that is allowing him to grow stronger; these dens of evil bear a strong resemblance to the dungeons in the legend of zelda series: in each one of them you will find a new ability, which will allow you to explore previously inaccessible areas (both inside and outside the dungeon) and that will be used in some way to defeat the boss of the dungeon in question.

speaking of bosses, they are fairly easy to deal with: this game as a whole is not maddeningly difficult, but i wouldn't say it's easy either, so it comes as a surprise that the bosses fall so easily, at least if you choose to use the arsenal at your disposition. they pretty much will never be a problem, unless you are trying to get the no-hit achievements, but even then they won't be a huge headache. i don't see it as a big problem, but to some it might be disappointing.

shantae's main weapon throughout this adventure is her signature hair whipping, but pistols and a scimitar will be added to her arsenal as the game progresses; other weapons, which on the previous game used the (now gone, for story reasons) magic meter (like the pike balls) became consumable itens. controls are very tight and responsible, a pretty important thing in this kind of game (well, an important thing in any kind of game, but especially in games that ask for precision like this one).

the game's tone is very lighthearted and humorous, with a good selection of charismatic and excentric character, as well as some fairly funny moments; the anime-influenced art style, while obviously not as good as one that's purely anime, is nice too.

there are a few problems here and there: you can't check if you already got all of the collectibles in an island without returning to risky's boat (being able to access this info on the menu would have been very useful, as it can be hard to keep track of it) and a (considerably long) insta-fail stealth section, which is not a big deal once you beat it, but will probably get on your nerves the first time. additionally, it can be somewhat difficult to know what to do next in some points (funnily enough, i didn't really have any problems with this, but i can see some people hitting a wall that will keep them from progressing, which can be very frustrating, especially when this wall comes from the game not giving you much information), although i think this is massively improved over risky's revenge.

these complaints, however, are small when compared to the game's achievements, and i think it's fair to say shantae and the pirate's curse is a very good videogame that deserves to be played by anyone with an interest in the genre, especially considering how cheap it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969385956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1482592754}
review:
While [i]"Shantae and the Pirate's Curse"[/i] is a lot like [i]"Shantae: Risky Boots' revenge"[/i] in some ways it's also unlike it in a lot of ways as well. It's ultimately still a platformer and a skill-attaining game that opens up more areas, but instead of an overworld you are given stage select screens. And instead of magic you have pirate items.

The first impression I had when I started playing was that the game was confirming the magic is no longer a thing due to the events of the last game (Risky Boots' Revenge). Honestly Shantae's transformations were a big part of what I found to be entrancing about the previous game. The fact that it was gone for good left me feelign liek there was a little hole in the heart of the game that wouldn't [i]quite[/i] be filled by the new skills. And really they didn't fill that hole but they were still decent game mechanics.

Shantae's friends played a more active role in this game than they did in the previous game which I totally approved of. In "Shantae: Risky Boots' Revenge" Rottytops, Bolo, Skye, and Uncle Mimic were ultimately just there to exist - they did nothing and were as forgetable as any town NPC save for the fact that they had unique appearances. In Shantae and the Pirate's Curse they actually take part as plot devices throughout the story. They're more like characters and less like decorations - very enjoyable characters too. 

On that note I was kinda meh about the whole teaming up with Risky Boots concept. When the only thing Risky does is sit at the dock and drive you from one stage to the other she becomes decoration. She does have her own part in the story of course, but she's given reasons all the time for why she cannot participate in anything which waters down the whole "teaming up" concept. I think a more interesting way to handle it would be to give Risky the pirate gear and leave Shantae some magic and transformations. It would have required different stage setups, but I feel it would have added something (pirate skills and a true teaming-up concept) without taking something (the enchantment of the transformations).

The items Shantae finds are all pirate items [spoiler]that were owned by Risky Boots before they were taken from her[/spoiler]: 

The [b]pistol[/b] is mostly only good at hitting distant puzzle switches unless it's tuned up to max level. The pistol basically replaces the fireball spell from the first game (1-damage). With no limit to bullets there's nothing stopping you from slinging all the bullets you want out there but it's still slower to shoot 5-8 bullets than it is to just go up and hit someone once with her hair. When maxed up (5-damage) the pistol is actually pretty okay as a weapon. 2-3 shots will kill most minor enemies.

The [b]hat[/b] feels kinda dumb in all honesty. It's basically a parachute or a glider depending how you use it. I feel it's just dumb that a hat is given noriety as a pirate item belonging to Risky [spoiler]and the Pirate Master[/spoiler] but all it does is catch wind like a parachute. As far as game mechanics go it's alright. When you get the cannon you'll never use it again except for the puzzles that require you use it. I will give the animation credit though; it looks adorable.

The [b]scimitar[/b] is simply a down-thrust while in the air. This works really well in combat as well as opening passages under Shantae's feet. You can also see the scimitar when using the boots which I think adds a little more flavor to the item than a one-trick pony (realistically a sword feels like it should be usable as a weapon but it is what it is. There are a few enemies that are much easier to fight when down-thrusting above them.

Risky's [b]boots[/b] are only usable on specific situations: primarily when there's enough flat land for running (technically you [i]can[/i] do a back-and-forth run and it'll still count as the building speed phase but no secret areas seem to be level with any of these areas I've tried it on which makes me think the developers might not have actually intended the back-and-forth movement to be a viable way to activate the boots). Once activated Shantae rushes in one direction dealing damage to anything that touches her and tearing down secret hidden walls. It's gimmicky as far as combat goes. You'll only end up using it when the stage was designed for it to be used since it requires prepping to pull off.

Risky's [b]cannon[/b] is basically this game's double-jump (though technically you can use it three times per jump). While in teh air the cannon will fire downwards and propell Shantae upwards. Once you get the cannon you'll use it a lot simply for the overwhelming convienence compared to Risky's hat. In combat it's okay but really Shantae's hair and scimitar take care of most things combat-wise anyway - it's good for avoidance though.


There were also certain skills you could learn from a shop in town:

The [b]Back Dash[/b] makes Shantae slide backwards just like the first game. You'll never use it. If it were a particularly fast slide it'd have merit but it slides her backwards at the same exact speed you could just move her in that direction. The animation put into it is lovely though.

The [b]Back Flip[/b] can be a life saver. typically if you're hit hard or hit at all while in the air you'll be knocked back and fall until you hit the ground. If you back flip you'll hop out of that state and be able to control yourself. I found this particularly importanbt when jumping from rope to rope over pits. Backflipping and gliding with a hat or double jumping with a cannon back to a rope kept me alive a dozen times or more.

The [b]Power Kick[/b] is just straight up stupid. It's a slow melee kick that does barely any better damage than the hair. The hair will do about 8 damage and can be spammed. The kick will do 10 damage but you'll take about a half second to do it. That's not even considering the button combo you have to do to pull it off. It is also shorter range if I remember right. You'll buy this to try it (because your curiousity will force you to) and then you'll never use it again. It's a badly implimented mechanic.

The level design - and the story surrounding each level - throughout Shantae was pretty cool all in all. It never took itself too seriously but it kept me enraptured all through the game. It even managed to make a filler boss battle feel like more than it was. The Shantae games seem to excel at this through sassy comedy and sexy-cute visuals.

I don't mind puzzles as long as they don't stop my progress. For the majority of the game this was okay. I was never hung up on anything long until the very last level. I'm of the belief that any game that has life bars or HP counts in them should stray away from including any instant killing factors (aside for bottemless pits anyway since that's just how it goes with pits). The final level is literally full of things designed to kill you in one hit. You'd probably think "well the last level is suppose to be hard, right?" and you would have merit to think this. But at the same time this game has you putting forth a lot of exploration and effort into finding heart squids to increase your HP. What is the point of this if when the final level comes you'll just die in one hit anyway? Is it challenging? Yes. It's also bad design.

Ultimately I did enjoy this game. The animations were sexy, adorable, and happy. The puzzles were mostly moderate or easy. The story was silly and fun. It didn't have quite the same flair as Risky's Revenge (the loss of magic really hit the alure), but I still recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039989097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1643, 'last_played': 1615724399}
review:
It's not a super long game (first blind any% run was 6-7 hours or so), but it has a decent amount of content. Level design is solid, with a few exceptions ([spoiler]mud bog island, the final level, & arguably tan line temple[/spoiler]). Soundtrack is pretty top, I still listen to it casually. Good speedrun game, if you're into that kind of thing.

I would recommend this when it's full price as well, but definitely pick it up whenever it goes on sale.




Also the girls are cute

author: {'steamid': '76561198038780024', 'num_games_owned': 890, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1559016431}
review:
I was pretty mad at WayForward for "DuckTales Remastered". But then I got this.
Simply put: it's pretty much the best platforming game I've played in last 5 years. Well, maybe "Shovel Knight" comes pretty close but that's it.
If you love nice platformers - get this one, you won't regret it.
Score: 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198047913005', 'num_games_owned': 1027, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 1132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1131, 'last_played': 1483471656}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8GdHEn3ybG4
[h1]Great 2D Platform Action with decent price[/h1]
I´m new to Shantae series and this was my first try at it. At first i thought the gameplay wasn´t complex enough, but as you progress through the game you will unlock different stuff that will get you abilities such as triple jump, cutlass/pistol that give you some cool functionalities. 

There is also unlockables in the game which are the Squid hearts and Dark Magics, collecting all dark magic will give you the "Good Ending" essentially and longer final boss fight so i recommend doing that. The Music is pretty neat and the characters offer lot of fan service and fun dialogue throughout the game. Shantae does share lot of similarities to Ori and the blind forest on its gameplay mechanics and similar setting where in the beginning of the game you don´t have that much things.

As you complete the game through first time you will unlock Pirate Mode which enables you to pretty much speedrun the game and get all pirate gear in the very first level.

[h1]The Better Side[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Around 18h of Gameplay among NewGamePlus so theres lot of replayability too
    [*]Great Platform Action & Fan service
    [*]Item System is very refreshing element to a platform game
    [*]The Characters have great designs and are very likeable
    [*]Great Level Design & Music
[/list]
[h1]The Worse Side[/h1]
[list]
    [*]The Games last level raises the difficulty quite alot among the last boss
    [*]Game doesn´t always tell u what do you need to do next, even the game is rather linear
    [*]Wish there was more audio dialogue, but i guess that doesn´t fit this type of a game in first place (Rather personal request)
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198048295196', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1559019917}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, the sequel to Shantae: Risky's Revenge. What do I have to say about this particular game?
EVERYTHING positive about this game, that's what!
The sprite design from the last game is still there, with some added animations here and there, there are a few added sounds for certain situations and scenes, the added island levels are a nice touch, the weapons you can use to solve certain puzzles was a nice way to temporarily replace Shantae's lack of magic, there is VERY little I hate about this game, other than a few types of enemies. There's also the lack of switching between different areas with those little... jump pads, is that what they are?
ANYWAYS, In my opinion, this game is much MUCH better than Risky's Revenge.
9.7/10, I WANT TO PLAY THIS AGAIN!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044856783', 'num_games_owned': 772, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1459711565}
review:
Quizá algunos se podrían dececpionar de que en este juego no tienes un mundo completamente interconectado sino que son varias islas entre las que puedes viajar cuando llegas a un puerto, pero a mi en lo personal me pareció que supera a su antecesor por mucho.
Tiene el mejor pixel art que he visto en un videojuego, con excelentes efectos de iluminación, una jugabilidad impecable y un muy buen ritmo de juego.
A mi no me gustó Risky's Revenge debido a un montón de pequeños detalles consecuencias de ser un port(como la falta de una opción para ver el mapa con sólo presionar un botón, el par de barras negras verticales omnipresentes, o el hecho de que el botón de cancelar en los menús tuviera que ser forzosamente el botón de salto), tengo el gusto de confirmar que Pirate's Curse no tiene esos problemas.
Le recomiendo este juego a cualquiera que busque un buen juego de plataformas o un buen metroidvania, y eso creo que aplica a todos los que se interesen lo suficiente en el juego como para leer este análisis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021441903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1459033204}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the third title of the Shantae series and continues the storyline from Risky's Revenge. This game features gorgeous (pixel)art, funky music, much love for details, lots of light-hearted humor, amicable characters, upgradable attacks, many secrets to be discovered and a good amount of platforming sequences.

The biggest drawback are the overpowered consumable items you can acquire in the shop (which also can be looted from enemies). Other than that I enjoyed this game greatly and would recommend it to everyone seeking a new metroidvania adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003970062', 'num_games_owned': 2038, 'num_reviews': 355, 'playtime_forever': 750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1458652179}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate’s Curse is a fairly easy 2D action platformer. You play as Shantae, a half-genie who is now just all human.

Oddly for a platforming game, there is actually a fair bit of story here; Shantae and Risky Boots, your sidekick/captain, are both reasonably well characterized, and the game makes a lot of call-backs to previous games… which I haven’t played. While the game IS comprehensible, I have no idea who any of these people are so the little side-stories which feature them lack meaning for me. That said, the game is full of funny dialogue, and Squid Baron in particular made me smile with his fourth-wall breaking rants. The game doesn’t take itself too seriously, and he was a particular highlight of that, but on the whole it worked reasonably well, even if it did rely a bit heavily on lampshade hanging for its humor.

Graphically, the game is reasonably attractive as well; the 2D Sprite graphics look pretty good, and the larger character portraits which appear while the characters are chatting look great. The game’s comedic style extends to its art, with the characters having amusingly exaggerated expressions. The game’s art is somewhat sexualized – the artist clearly loves voluptuous women, and the hips of the game’s female characters don’t lie – but it wasn’t to the point where it bothered me, and it is often played for laughs, particularly given one of the characters is an attractive female zombie. Plus, let’s face it – a lot of people like looking at pretty ladies, so that’s really probably a plus for a lot of folks. If that sort of thing DOES bother you, though, this is likely a game which will trigger your distaste, as several of the female characters are a bit bouncy.

Squid Baron, again, really shines here – his sprite is amusing enough, but his character art is great, and his hyper-exaggerated expressions really help sell his silliness. 

As for the gameplay itself, the game is… well, okay. It is a reasonable 2D platformer, but frankly, it is quite easy for almost its entire length. The game, unlike most such games, grants the player an inventory menu containing 12 items, each of which the player can carry 9 of – and this includes vast numbers of healing items, as well as items which block projectiles, damage enemies passively, and greatly increase Shantae’s attacks. You accumulate them over the game, you don’t really need to use them too frequently (especially once you get used to the way the game plays), and by the later portions of the game you will have acquired vast numbers of them, to the point where nothing can realistically challenge you. There is an in-game shop as well, selling items in exchange for gems dropped by pots you break and enemies you kill, allowing you to further top-up on stuff, as well as buy upgrades for your attacks which allow you to deal more damage.

The net result of this is by about halfway through the game you run out of upgrades to buy and pretty much end up with gigantic piles of items in your inventory which you don’t even need to use. I started using some in the second-to-last dungeon just because I had so many, but I still had enough gems to be capped out by the end. I did use the damage-enhancement items on the bosses because there is absolutely no reason not to, and it makes getting the various no-damage achievements that much easier.

Honestly, the achievements are the most challenging part of the game; beating it is almost trivial, and beating some of the bosses without taking damage is quite simple, while for others, it is moderately more difficult. This sort of thing – along with a few other random optional achievements – are likely to contribute almost all of the difficulty the game holds. It is only in the final two dungeons that the game really starts trying to challenge the player, and while the final dungeon does contain some pretty challenging portions (and a sharp difficulty spike), the final two bosses are strangely easy, with only the optional form of the final boss posing any real challenge to the player.

That said, the game isn’t that short. While it seemed short while playing it – and the ample save points made it easy to get out of – the in-game timer said it took me a little under 9 hours to 100% the game. I’d guess it probably took about 10.5-11 hours including the time spent getting the side achievements. That said, if you’re looking for a really substantial experience, this probably isn’t it – a lot of the time in-game was spent doing relatively unchallenging things, and there was some backtracking involved in gathering various collectibles. In terms of fresh content, you’re likely looking at 6 hours or so of gameplay, maybe a bit more.

All in all, this is a decent but not amazing game. I recently played Strider, and that game felt a lot more satisfying to me than this did. Not to say that Shantae was bad, but it just wasn’t exceptional; it is a decent filler game, but if you’re looking for a high-end platformer, you’re better off looking elsewhere. This is middle of the road; it probably won’t be disappointing, but it won’t impress you particularly either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995028741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1458507181}
review: Solidna metroidvania w kolorowym, pogodnym settingu. W grze wcielamy się w pół-dżinkę (neologizm over 9000) Shantae, która wraz z dawną przeciwniczką Risky musi pokonać króla piratów i przełamać jego klątwę. Z biegiem czasu zdobywamy kolejne elementy pirackiego ekwipunku, który pozwala nam docierać w nowe miejsca i odnajdywać tajne pomieszczenia w już odwiedzonych. Możemy także wykorzystać znalezione klejnoty by ulepszać nasze możliwości bojowe lub uczyć sie nowych. Tytuł jest ładny, dość wymagający i potrafi przykuć na klika dobrych godzin. Jeśli lubicie Castlevanie polecam gorąco.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043968215', 'num_games_owned': 10014, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1458500174}
review:
Ok, there's no need to lie, but boobs made me want to start playing the game, but stayed for the platoforming, which is really responsive, progression of the story and the level exploration is intuitive, a  fair variety of powers, sometimes new unlocks will require you to revisit places. 

I have not played the previous titles, but the story was easy to understsand and it was quite enjoable, filled with humor and twists. 

The difficulty raises gradually with the progression, the boss battles are enjoyable, there are plenty of save points to not be required to replay big chuncks of levels. The artwork is amazing.

Would have liked more voiceacting than just a few words and moans (don't get me wrong, I can't get enough of those, I would have even enjoyed more, ppl walking in the room hearing the sounds coming from speakers might have considered I was doing something else). The soundtrack is ok. 

I would recommend this title for both casual players and hardcore platformer gamers, the learning curve is a bit more on the easy side in the beginning but might become difficult near the end.

P.S. Need to thank GreaT for the game, which can be easily be finished in a day or two if played intensely, I finished it in a weekend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079341221', 'num_games_owned': 878, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1549681215}
review:
Genre: Action Platformer + Minor RPG Elements

+ Positive
Offers a good challenge for veterans of the genre but others might breeze through just fine.

The pixel art is top notch and the sprites animation's are excellently smooth.

Enviroments and Dungeons have their unique style 

Solid 60 FPS ( For le master race)

Easy on Hardware

- Negative
Save Points are a bit too far spread out that might cause annoyance for newcomers

Starting HP is only Two Hearts ( Each heart contains four HP), But can be upgraded by exploring Levels.

The ending could of been better

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the best in the Franchise, and will keep players hooked in for around 8-12 hours depending on your completionism.

author: {'steamid': '76561198204547120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1595695421}
review: If you liked the good old Capcom jump'n runs in the beginning and middle of the 90´s then you should give Shantae - The pirates curse a try! Colorful 16bit retro graphics and sound that will blast you back into the 90´s, The difficulty is pretty demanding especially in the last level....in relation to the other levels i would say it´s a little bit unfair and frustrating. My controller has now some bite scars...eeekk!! But i´ve defeated the pirate master and the frustrating feelings about the last level are blown away. Tip: Use bubble, milk and spikes at the boss fight.....

review: Shantae, una genio, no genio humana no humana pirata no pirata que esta RODEADA COMPLETAMENTE DE MAR Y LUCHANDO CONTRA PIRATAS y obviamente no sabe nadar, la primera vez que he tocado el agua ALT+F4, no tiene puto sentido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013088993', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1497368458}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse seems to strip almost every recognisable mechanic out of the first two games - and is a far more enjoyable game because of it. 

Gone are the clunky transformations, replaced with a plethora of new mobility/combat items for Shantae to unlock that significantly increases the overall dynamism of the game in comparison to its predecessors. Even the maps seem to be more thoughfully designed this time around.

The soundtrack - composed by Jake Kaufman - is also ridiculously good.

This is by far the best game in the Shantae series. Heartily recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993646558', 'num_games_owned': 2168, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1458913264}
review: Enjoyable. Not much to say against the game, if anything. If you like platformers, this is one of the better recent ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976799778', 'num_games_owned': 1287, 'num_reviews': 564, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1457906640}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse ist der dritte Teil der Reihe und ein weiterer Vertreter des Metroidvania Genres, welchem ich nicht abgeneigt bin. Am Anfang irritierte mich Shantae allerdings mit dem sehr kindlichen Humor. Wenn man diesen ertragen kann, eröffnet sich eine grundsolide Hatz auf immer neue Gegenstände um auch die letzten Geheimnisse zu finden.

Leider ist die Steuerung in Shantae nicht ganz so präzise, wie ich es mir für solch ein Spiel erwünscht hätte. Dafür ist der Schwierigkeitsgrad gerade in der ersten Hälfte sehr einfach. Durch die sehr fairen Rücksetzpunkte, sollte es wohl fast jeder bis zur fünften Insel schaffen. Leider ist das letzte Level auf einmal so schwer, dass ich das Spiel dann doch nur frustresistenten Spielern empfehlen kann.

4/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198052817358', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1457896387}
review:
J'ai beaucoup aimé ce jeu. 

Il surpasse le précédent jeu de Shantae en tout point. Les environnements sont beaucoup plus diversifiés et il y a plus de monstres différents à combattre. Le seul petit défaut, c'est peut-être le niveau final, qui me semble beaucoup trop difficile si je me met dans la peau d'un enfant qui réussit à parvenir à la fin. J'avais l'impression de jouer à un jeu difficile comme Castle in the Darkness plutôt qu'à Shantae!

En ce qui concerne le gameplay, les pouvoirs de Shantae, cette fois-ci, ne sont plus des pouvoirs des transformation, mais plutôt des armes de pirate. Ces dernières ne sont pas seulement utiles pour accéder à de nouvaux endroits, mais également lors des combats contre les ennemis et les boss. Plusieurs armes sont également importantes pour augmenter les chances de survie lors des sauts de plateforme en plateforme. 

En ce qui concerne l'histoire, elle est banale et elle contient une certaine dose d'humour, sans jamais pour autant être trop vulgaire. Le visuel, de son côté, est très bien. Tout est coloré et a un style dessin animé. Finalement, la durée de vie - une dizaine d'heures - est très raisonnable pour le style de jeu, surtout qu'elle n'est pas augmentée de façon artificielle contrairement à ce que l'on voit dans d'autres jeux. 

Je donne à ce jeu une note de 9 sur 10, ce qui est deux points de plus par rapport à ce que j'avais donné pour le précédent jeu de la série Shantae. J'espère que le prochain jeu sera tout aussi bon!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999542156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1455381662}
review:
Look, I'll save you some time.

This game is good. Real good. Nintento-era platformer good. 

The writing is a little silly, and the grammar is sometimes bad. Also, I can't say much for some of the art.

But the rest of the art is great, and the gameplay is stellar, and the challenge is spot-on, and the music is bangin'. If you have been itching for something to kickstart your nostalgia, this might be the ticket. And even if you aren't, if you've ever appreciated a jump bark, you'll enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996899960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1457755070}
review:
A well developed metroidvania with retro-spirit.
I ran out of metroidvania games with "cool" main characters and decided to try this genie girl. Turned out to be amazingly good. The controls are really good and it's a proper metroidvania which means lots of exploration, lots of powers and platforming mechanics, lots of variety, etc. This is a proper's franchise title and it shows, there's depth and a lot of well placed secrets with dozens of stuff.
If you're into metroidvanias and/or platformers this is a must have, with a light emphasis on the fighting aspects this is can be appreciated by the casual platformer player but also can be enjoyed by the other spectrum of players searching for interesting mazes, small puzzles and overall exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025159964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1457311140}
review:
Hadn't played a shantae game until this one. Not bad at all. A somewhat simple metroidvania platformer, not too easy not too hard. It was odd not knowing any of the characters, kind of like skipping a book in a series, but easy enough to learn and fairly understand everyone. Charming characters, humurous dialogue, fantastic sprite art and great soundtrack by Virt (Shovel Knight Composer!).

My only issues were: it felt a bit short, especially since a decent portion of the game is running back and forth. And the difficulty for the last boss ramps much farther than I felt it should. Only reason I managed to clear it was I happened to have enough healing items stockpiled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110865386', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1457301467}
review:
There are many, complicated and important things in this game that you have to know before getting it.

1. Boobs
2. Boobs
3. Boobs
4. Platforming
5. Evil Pirates
6. Evil Pirate Boobs
7. Zombies
8. Zombie Boobs
9. Giant Scorpion Centaurs
10. Giant Scorpion Centaurs with Boobs
11. Fish
12. Fish with Boobs

Shantae and the PIrate's Curse is a 2D Platformer That, Like it's predecessors, Pays great homage to SNES Sidescrollers.
I'll get down to the Pros and Cons on this one, Don't wanna spoil too much of the story.

Pros - 
Boobs
Whipping shit with your hair
Dancing Women
Memorable Enemies, Bosses, and Dungeons, some of which have Boobs
Amazing Music, Seriously, I was dancing along with it.
Well implimented DK Barrel-like mechanics
Much like Megaman, you learn by playing the game. No tutorials here, folks.

Cons -
Platforming can get a bit Wonky
Giant One-eyed Frogs
Unwanted stimulation to the genital region


9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197982480003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1483151537}
review: The first two Shantae games were charmingly designed, but a bit of a mess gameplay wise. With Pirate's Curse, WayForward seems to have drawn what made people fall in love with the idea of these games and jettison the clunkier parts for a streamlined and breezy experience that serves as a tidy little cap to the series. The basic gameplay retains the Zelda II/Castlevania formula of side-scrolling exploration and power-up collecting, while ditching the more tedious map traversal of the first two games in favor of a simple level select hub. For plot reasons, the transformation dances are replaced with pirate relics that handily map to your controller's various buttons. While the core platforming and boss battles are still tempered by a near endless well of health items, there's enough meat to the level design and platforming to keep it from feeling like you're blasting through the game with little resistance. And the impressive sprite work, soundtrack, and, ehem, signature sense of humor that have come to characterize the series are all intact. While I wouldn't say WayForward necessarily knocked this one out of the park, Shantae and the Pirate's curse is a respectable RBI.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004767598', 'num_games_owned': 815, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1457179265}
review:
언젠간 해봐야지~ 하다가... 이제서야 한 네 시간쯤 해보고 평가 남겨봅니다.

사실 해보기 전에도 좋은 유저 평가들이 있어서 꽤 높은 기대치를 가지고 있던  게임인데

해보고 나니 일단 평가에 추천부터 누르고 쓰게 되었습니다.

일단 영상보시고 음 맘에든다 하는 느낌이 오시면 바로 구매하셔도 좋습니다.

2016년 3월 5일 기준으로 98퍼 긍정에 평가수가 모자라서 매우 긍정적인데 이 비율이면 원래는 압도적으로 긍정적이죠. 

괜히 평가가 좋은게 아니었다는 소감입니다.

-장점-
도트덕후들의 덕심을 흔드는 적절한 도트 
귀엽고 섹시한 캐릭터 일러스트(중요)
매우쉬운듯 하면서도 그렇게까지 쉽지만은 않은 난이도

-단점- 
맵간 이동이 좀 불편함. (몹 무한젠인 구간이 많음)
추가되는 능력을 얻고 난 뒤에 다시 맵순회를 해서 아이템을 모아야하는 데 강제귀환이 없음..
퀘스트 리스트가 없는 진행방식으로 직접 진행용 퀘스트 보고지점을 기억해둬야함.
(어지간하면 플레이타임을몰아서 한번에 깨시는게 좋습니다.)


팁 : 최대 체력을 높여주는 수집품은 4개단위로 사용하실 수 있으므로 너무 어렵다고 생각되신다면 올리는게 좋습니다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119795897', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 865, 'last_played': 1481708614}
review:
Shantae系列的第三作
此作依然是一貫的Wonderboy+Metroid風格
對應前一代的結局，所以本作取消了系列作一貫的變身魔法系統，取而代之的是各種特殊道具的靈活運用來進行戰鬥跟解迷
各方面來說都是相當優質的遊戲

優點：
1.相較於Shantae: Risky's Revenge，操作有了很明顯的改進，跳躍曲線也變的更好操作
2.雖然取消了傳統的變身系統，但特殊道具的運用卻比變身更直覺，而且不需要變身的前置動作（跳舞），意外的反而讓整體流程更爽快
3.音樂極佳，前作音樂已經很不錯了，本作的音樂亦是更出色，尤其是Saliva Island的BGM真的很棒
4.地圖設計變的更雷同於Super Metroid的補格子設計，使整個探索流程可以說是更順暢
5.未收集的要素會直接標示於地圖上，不需要再地毯式搜索
6.總之各方面相較前作（Shantae: Risky's Revenge）都有飛躍性進步，如果喜歡前作的玩家基本上不會失望

缺點：
1.如果可以把地圖設定成單鈕開啟可能會更好
2.手把鍵位似乎是不能更動，但前作Shantae: Risky's Revenge卻可以改....
3.零星的幾個部份解迷提示略少，但基本上算不上什麼問題

總結：
優質的探索類動作遊戲，而且相比前作確實的感受到進步
同時明顯的可以看出系統方向更偏向Metroid，不僅僅是地圖的方面，有幾個部份更是讓人有刻意致敬（？）的感覺
例如衝刺技能一樣都需要助跑距離才能加速，Tan Line Temple的潛行橋段也有點神似metroid zero mission
甚至主角在最終boss戰跟Super Metroid一樣有爆氣演出
如果是不熟悉英文的中文使用者可能會在劇情道具的交付上卡關，但基本上迷宮內的機關都不會太複雜，解迷相較於前作是比較簡單些，應該是不會太讓人挫折
總個來說是完全對的起這個價位的遊戲，平衡上也是恰到好處，不會讓玩家覺得太難，或是簡單到可以無腦過關
大致上是沒有太多地方可以挑惕的遊戲，期待WayForward的下一款Shantae: Half-Genie Hero可以做的更棒

另外讓人疑惑的一點是，從收藏庫內點選Shantae and the Pirate's Curse→右鍵→內容
可以看到這款遊戲是有語言選項的，而且是包括日語、法語、德語等多國語言，但即使調整了遊戲內語言也不會更動
難不成是還在進行其他語言的製作？

author: {'steamid': '76561197975703239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1454725085}
review:
A game I had a lot of fun with, but it has quite a bit of flaws. Having never played a Shantae and hearing it was a metroidvania style game, I was dissapointed when it turned out to be a mostly linear 2d zelda affair. The backtracking, unlike in regular metroidvania which makes exploring the world and unlocking new paths exciting and lore-richening, seemed like a tedious chore in this game. Almost like filler that they had to do in order for the game to be just a bit longer. The good thing is that the fast travel things you can buy in the one shop (yeah unfortunately there's only one shop in the very paltry main city) in this game are cheap.

Now some positives. The game plays and looks well, for the most part. The animations, music, and overall style of the game are on point. Usually I find that when a game panders towards an audience it is bad. At a cursory glance one look at Shantae almost looks like its pandering toward that harem big boobied fetish, and there's no denying that it is. Since the game is so tongue and cheek about the whole thing, and Shantae's dialogue is genuinely that of a cute character, I am down with it. It's not one of those visual novels that wants you to fap every second, the big boobs are there to be enjoyed in the background and in this case work as a fine character trait.

The dungeons, although entirely linear, had great platforming. Some rooms have you dying over and over to reach the goal, which I found quite challenging and awesome. The game starts out pretty easy, but about halfway through there is a major difficulty spike. Each and every boss in the game was excellently animated and a thrill to fight. All of the upgrades of the game got better and better, and by the end I truly felt like an OP character. This is how upgrades should be done, with each upgrade being a standalone good weapon, but also synergizing with the previous upgrades aquired. 

And since this review, although I liked the game, pointed out some flaws let me just point out one small thing that annoyed me to heck. It doesn't affect the gameplay, it doesn't affect the enjoyment, it's just that when the score and the graphics and the gameplay and everything else has such high production value why does the pause menu look so crappy? Like they used they paintbucket tool on the regular blue setting and called it a day. I know pause menu's aren't the most exciting part of a game, but it always looked out of place.

Well anyway, despite the shortcomings and filler the game was cool. I'll pick up the next Shantae game if it's cheap and if it ever comes out. (At the time of this review the game has been in kickstarter hell for quite a bit of time.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197991261761', 'num_games_owned': 872, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1459158297}
review:
Great art direction, music is fairly catchy, and the controls are relatively slick. Some attempt at story isn't terrible

But the platforming is pretty bad and the level design leaves a lot to be desired. Just the mechanics of the monsters and the flow of the level is just tedious at times for no reason. Platforming is supposed to reward skill but often is just slow and finicky which breaks the fun. Levels and monsters don't always even have a gimmick. 

I feel like they were going for a Super Adventure Island II (SNES) type game, but forgot to look at every game after to find out what they can do to bring life to a level besides length.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076721797', 'num_games_owned': 915, 'num_reviews': 778, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1454967225}
review:
This is pretty much an improvement over Risky's Revenge in about every way. It's longer, more balanced, faster-paced, and in general just more fun to play. Though I'd also say it's still far from a perfect game.

A few things to note right off the bat; while this does have a metroidvania-style powerup system and shop and all that, the game map is divided up strictly into levels, each level being decently sized, but yeah there's no interconnected map here. The game does have an actual map system though, something that was sorely missing from Risky's Revenge. And as well you'll easily know when you've collected everything in an area since it shows on the world map.

The main game mechanics, Risky's various items, are much more fun than the dancing of the rest of the series. No more slowing to a crawl to perform a dance that's mostly only useful in a few select areas, this time you can pull any of your tools out at a whim and practically every one of them has uses both in platforming and in combat.

The pistol is, well, a pistol. You're gonna be using it for ranged attacks a lot, and though it's fairly weak compared to other weapons it's still plenty useful. The hat is mainly used for platforming purposes to glide through the air, but it's pretty solid. I do think it should pull out faster, there were a lot of points where I felt it was a struggle to use because of how slow it is to pull out (especially in one spot in the last dungeon that's waaay harder than it should be). The scimitar lets you bounce on enemies as well as break floor tiles below you, though you have almost no horizontal movement when using it, which would've been nice and allowed for some clever puzzles, but oh well. The boots are possibly the most fun item, letting you charge rampantly through everything, zoom zoom plowing through enemies, it's so much fun. Wish it was mapped to a button rather than to a context-sensitive timer, but it'd probably be horribly broken otherwise, I suppose. And the cannon gives you three extra jumps AND another aerial attack, allowing for safer fighting and pretty much breaking all the jumping puzzles in the game.

The icing on the cake is the mode you unlock after clearing the game for the first time that allows you to play through the game with all the tools from the start, speeding up the game quite a bit and allowing for some -fun- strategies against earlier bosses.

The bosses, then, let's talk about them. They're... a mixed bag. I like some of them, while some others are a bit... bad. The boss of the fifth island, for one, misleads you into thinking you should be fighting it with the gun since that's the most convenient weapon to use, but that is definitely NOT the weapon you actually want to use, you want to hair-whip it to pull it down to the ground, and... eh... I really don't like that boss because of the bad first impression it left on me. The boss on the sixth island is relatively easy, sure, but annoying since it's literally RNG and little else. I'm not really a fan of the movement RNG in these bosses in general, the third island boss, fourth island boss, and first phase of the final boss have it the worst in this regard, though maybe it's because I had to spend time grinding to no-damage kill these bosses, but it's a minor gripe. Overall the bosses are more good than bad though, in the end.

The enemies and combat in general are also pretty solid, there's a few that annoy, a few too tanky, a few too powerful, and the first area of the fifth island is just a huge pain because of rampant enemy spam, but in general it's balanced well with the platforming. There's a fair number of enemies back from Risky's Revenge, but plenty of new ones thrown into the mix as well. The platforming is also generally pretty interesting and creative, as are the few puzzles scattered throughout the maps. The exploration elements are there, too, even with the map designs, though some parts play out almost like an adventure game, trying to figure out where to go next or finding a specific item you need to progress the story, but poking around older areas with new tools tends to produce results most of the time. It's a very solid, enjoyable experience on the whole.

The game also looks great, the spritework and animations are lovely, the level graphics and background graphics are all nice, the character portraits look great. The game also sounds great, there's some reused music from Risky's Revenge but a lot of the original tracks are just generally nice and never really wear out, plus it helps that there's quite a ton of music in the game in general, 2-3 map tracks per island, multiple cutscene themes, a few boss themes, really no shortage of good tunes.

It's really hard to fault this game much, I had a few gripes with it but nothing that adds up to a major problem, and most importantly, it's fun. That's all I really need a game to be, in the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031517241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1454372009}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a classic 2D action platformer with metroidvania elements. However, compared to most generic modern platformers, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse distinguishes itself by the highest level of quality, with WayForward's pedigree in game development clearly visible throughout the whole game. Actually, this game is a part of an established series, being the third and latest installment to date.

The first thing you'll notice is the overall quality of graphics and animation, with the game being mostly done in awesome high-quality pixel art. Shantae also takes advantage of modern platforms by using high-resolution character sprites for dialogue segments. Everything looks even better in motion — the animations are surprisingly detailed and very smooth, so the fact that there are a lot of them in the game is a cherry on top. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse combines regual 2D pixel-art and modern visual effects, which look together better than you'd think. The game runs at 60 FPS, like platformers used to, and actually, should be played. Super smooth animations and super precise movement — eye candy and a soothing experience where the character moves exactly like you want them to.

Music and sound effects in Shantae and the Pirate's Curse don't fall short of the graphics, with the game featuring a large number of high quality and atmospheric music tracks, which greatly fit not only the overall game, but individual levels and characters as well. And since we're on the topic of levels, it should be mentioned that level design in Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is great, both in terms of visuals and platforming. It's clear that developers at WayForward are masters of old school platforming, employing challenging and interesting design, traps, secrets and everything else that makes this game feel like such classics as Megaman.

Every world in the game (seven in total) not only has its own visual theme and music, but is also designed around different types of platforming that you'll need to employ. Some levels feature platforming that is heavily influenced by games such as Megaman, while metroidvania elements present themselves mainly through the world being a bunch of inter-connected locations, presence of hidden areas and new locations slowly becoming accessible with new item acquisition.

Unlike previous games in the series, where Shantae used her magic, this time you're faced with the fact that she lost it (in the previous game), so she must overcome the challenges with various items that she'll come across through the game. Usually in a game like this items would be for unlocking / adding abilites, and weapons would be used for fighting, but in Shantae even weapons unlock new abilities to the player.    

The game world consists of different islands that are unlocked after completing boss fights. These boss fights aren't that difficult, especially if you stock up on healing items, but fun nonetheless. Bosses are very large, and have a cool design, which comes in variety - a huge-ass tank straight outta Metal Slug, a misspelled fire-breathing monstrosity Dagron, and of course, an abomination to your screen space in form of the final boss (true form only).

To sum it up, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a joy to play, not only because of visuals and sound, but stellar level design and gameplay. An interesting cute protagonist also helps. For some reason people mostly missed out on this gem, with SteamSpy estimating sales at ~25K. But you definitely should buy and play this game, even if you aren't a fan of the genre.

P.S. For more awesome hidden gems, follow the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10722089/]CRIMINALLY Low Sales[/url] steam curator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046562545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1453780334}
review: It's a pretty good game. A metroidvania type platformer, with some unique characters and enemies. The bosses are all great to fight and put up a good challenge, the levels are nicely designed and frequently incorporate powerups you obtained in previous "dungeons". The main plotline is a tad cliche and you'll see the ending a mile away, but that doesn't make the journey any less fun (especially because some of the situations you end up in are absurd). Overall I'd recommend this to anyone. If there's any one flaw that I can find with the game, it's that you'll never normally get enough money to buy all the upgrades; you'll actually be required to farm money at some point in the game if you want the 100% completion, which gets a bit tedious.

review: I didn't like the game at first because I though it was too easy but the difficulty certainly ramped up later! author: {'steamid': '76561197999599511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1452982253}
review: Great sequel to Risky's Revenge, replacing the transformations from that game with pirate weapons that give Shantae upgrades such as increased attack range, dashes and greater jumping ability. As with the last game, this is a retro action platformer with hair-whipping as the main attack and tight controls coupled with the aforementioned upgrades to help you traverse the different worlds and dungeons. This is also another stellar musical turn by Jake "virt" Kaufman, who made the previous game's soundtrack and has upgraded some of it's themes whilst composing new funky electronic tracks (the soundtrack can be found [url=https://virt.bandcamp.com/album/shantae-and-the-pirates-curse-ost]here[/url]).

author: {'steamid': '76561198130694219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 842, 'last_played': 1452739243}
review:
wayforwardから発売された、shantaeシリーズ第3弾。
初期作は残念ながらGBなのでsteamにはありませんが、この作品単体でも充分に満足できる内容となっております

話の内容としては、主人公shantaeと前作の敵Riskyが共闘してさらに大きな敵と戦う、という王道展開です
操作できるのは、前作同様shantaeだけですが
なぜRiskyと敵対していたか気になる人は、前作を買ってみるのもありかもしれません

ゲーム自体としては、とてもとっつきやすいメトロイドヴァニアのACTでしょうか
開発元のwayforwardがかなり日本に影響されているらしく、イラストレイターは日本人を起用していたり、謎解き要素などは有名なゼルダシリーズやメトロイドを髣髴とさせるためすんなりとプレイできます
トレーラームービーは若干ネタバレが多いですが、本当にムービー通りの操作ができるため一度見てみると良いかもしれません

ゲーム自体の難易度もしっかりと考えて調整してあり、程々の難易度で楽しむことが出来ます
アクションが苦手な方も回復アイテムゴリ押しでほぼなんとかなるため、難易度で詰まるといったことはほぼ無いといっていいでしょう

気になる点としては、
・新しいアクションは基本ダンジョンでのアンロック式のため、最初のうちはあまり多彩なことができない
・お使いミッションではないが、新しい場所に行くために同じ場所を往復したり特定の人物を探すために走り回る必要がある
・steam版は日本語非対応のため、英語がわからないと誰をどこに探しに行けば良いのかわからなくなる
この辺りでしょうか

現在3DSで日本語版も発売されているので、英語が苦手な方はそちらを購入するのも一つの手ではあります
そこまで難しい英語でもないので、雰囲気で読み進めても特に問題はありませんが。

総評すれば、かなり質の高いACTゲーであり、定価の値段でも充分に元が取れる内容となっております
値引き自体もちょこちょこされていますので、ぜひ購入して遊んでみてはいかがでしょうか

author: {'steamid': '76561198086162912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1452077213}
review:
The original Shantae was difficult to enjoy due to the restrictions of the Gameboy's screen, forcing you to play with a very small field of view. Risky's Revenge had confusing maps and slow gameplay that eventually turned me away from it. 

But here we finally have what I can confidently call an excellent Shantae game. The gameplay is so much faster here and the world has been split up into different islands, making map navigation no longer an issue. And the music, man, I swear Jake Kaufman gets better with every album he releases. Rave in the Grave just blew my mind when I first heard it. It's so catchy. And I was really surprised when Scorching Dunes started out kinda generic, but then slowly evolved into a tune very reminiscent of the old Sonic games. And the tracks actually change a little bit on their second loop, keeping them from getting repetitive.

But of course, there are issues. The Monster Milk items, which greatly boost your attack power, make most boss fights utterly worthless. The only boss that I kinda enjoyed was the Steel Maggot, because it had mechanics that went beyond just using the item you got in that dungeon. You need a little bit of observation and trial and error to beat it.

Here's the problem with all of the Shantae games. Your most effective method of attack is a hair whip that can't be used while moving unless you're in the air. The devs then have to design the entire game based around that limitation. So levels are a lot of running, then stopping to attack, then running, so on and so forth. It's a lot like Castlevania Simon's Quest. Most regular enemies are no challenge and only serve to hinder your progress. (This is also why I appreciate the new pirate items so much. They let you speed through areas much more easily.) 

Bosses are pretty much the same. They all have periods where they just stand still and let you hit them repeatedly, which is required because of the limitation of Shantae's hair. It's a fault by design and should really be changed for the next game, Half-Genie Hero. I should never get to a final boss and not be intimidated. 

But hey, Wayforward isn't the biggest company out there. They did what they could and I think they did great. The art, the music, the characters, the humor, and the improved gameplay thanks to the pirate items make Shantae and the Pirate's Curse a memorable experience. I just hope that Half-Genie Hero doesn't squander the achievements made in this game and takes steps backwards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198221484468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 735, 'last_played': 1453321422}
review:
Ancora una volta Wayforward ci consegna un altro fantastico Shantae, questa volta più ampio e più divertente che mai!
è incredibile come Wayforward sia rimasta l'unica casa non indie (anche se si comporta da tale) che sappia produrre questo tipo di giochi. Il punto è che nel giocare questi giochi ci si aspetta di avere fra le mani un clone di Metroid o Castlevania (come il nome del genere ci suggerisce) ma Shantae è veramente qualcosa di diverso: non c'è nessun collegamento con queste due saghe e il gameplay, seppur ispiratissimo a questo tipo di giochi, dista ampiamente dalle saghe che hanno definito questo genere... ma andiamo per gradi!

(Saranno necessari richiami alla storia del capitolo precedente. Se non volete spoiler riguardo Shantae: Risky's Revenge evitate di leggere i primi 4 o 8 righi a seconda della visualizzazione)

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse è il terzo gioco di questa splendida saga. L'uso di Shantae è un po' diverso rispetto allo scorso capitolo, questa volta potrà contare solamente su abilità da umana visto che, il nostro mezzo genio, ha perso l'uso della magia nello scorso capitolo. Non ci saranno più danze del ventre e trasformazioni, stavolta Shantae potrà contare solamente sulle sue nuove armi da "umana" (nonchè i suoi splendidi capelli); il gameplay risulta dunque sia rinnovato che fedele ai capitoli precedenti. Le mappe sono decisamente più ampie rispetto al capitolo precedente e, nella forma, ricordano molto le mappe del primo gioco per Gameboy color (uscito alla fine del suo ciclo vitale, praticamente contemporaneo con il gameboy advance) infatti non sarà presente la navigazione su più livelli come in Risky's Revenge. In compenso, Shantae stavolta navigherà per diverse isole nel corso della sua avventura offrendo dunque al giocatore molta varietà e aumentando la longevità del gioco. Utilissima invece la nuova grafica per le mappe in perfetto stile Metroid/Castlevania dove saranno segnati i punti di salvataggio (in rosso per giunta), le entrate dei dungeons e i punti rilevanti. Saranno presenti inoltre molti riferimenti musicali dei giochi del passato insieme a moltissime canzoni nuove e ben composte. Rimossi i Magic Jars ma introdotti le magie nere, utili per completare il gioco al 100%, e i "Calamacuori" (stavolta il gioco è completamente tradotto) che, come i frammenti di cuore in Zelda, una volta collezionati quattro di questi e portati dalla porno fabbra (il fabbro femmina?) di Scuttle town, questa potrà aumentare di un'unità la nostra vita massima. Nessun sistema di level up è stato introdotto, Shantae dovrà ancora recarsi in negozio per comprare (più volte stavolta) shampoo e balsamo per aumentare la forza del suo attacco primario e gli upgrades delle sue nuove armi. Come al solito i personaggi sono molto spiritosi anche se, la totale traduzione del gioco, non coglie appieno lo humor velato della lingua originale (ho visto un paio di screenshot in inglese di alcune battute e devo dire che rendono poco in italiano). Tuttavia le battute riescono comunque a strappare molte risate e lo stile grafico, soprattutto dei bellissimi artwork a cura di Inti Creates, è semplicemente perfetto e decisamente superiore a Risky's Revenge. Come già accennato, il gioco è molto più grande rispetto al precedente ma questo, soprattutto nei primi livelli, risulta molto facilitato e se come me ci giocherete per più ore consecutivamente (per via magari di un'influenza che vi costringerà a letto) rischierete di finirlo molto in fretta! Qui però, in sostituzione della modalità magica del vecchio gioco, sarà possibile sbloccare la modalità pirata che consentirà a Shantae di tenere tutte le armi ottenibili nei dungeons sin dall'inizio, consentendo di completare il gioco nel minor tempo possibile (e poter sbloccare dunque gli altri sfondi del menù e forse dei finali alternativi).

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse è un gioco validissimo che merita di essere comprato ad occhi chiusi! Tanti i miglioramenti e tante le promesse per altri capitoli ancora più belli ed immersivi. Wayforward si supera ancora una volta, stavolta forse di poco, ma tanto quel che basta di poter parlare di miglioramenti e per rinfrescare una saga già fresca di suo! In mia opinione Shantae and the Pirate's Curse rialza veramente lo standard per questo stile di gioco (in attesa forse di Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night) ed è un action/platformer veramente eccezionale. Se siete amanti dello stile Metroidvania questo è un gioco che non vi deve assolutamente sfuggire! Altamente raccomandato! 

9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198060143410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1451696361}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is an incredibly fun 2D metroidvania game. Tight controls, enjoyable mechanics, great looking pixel art style and amazing soundtrack (that you can get it for free or by donating at least a dollar on Jake Kaufman's website, which I would recommend the latter because his work is great and he deserves it.)

The story is full of funny and witty dialogues with really enjoyable characters. I would recommend before playing this game to play the other 2 prequels or at least Shantae: Risky's Revenge (which is also on Steam) because this game follows directly after the story of Risky's Revenge and it has many references to the previous games. While I did prefer Pirate's Curse over Risky's Revenge, I still would highly recommend playing both as they are great. Pirate's Curse defiinitely improved many things from the previous games and it's why I consider it my favorite out of the 3 games.

If you like 2D metroidvania games with a witty and enjoyable story, I'd absolutely recommend you to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094303024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 696, 'last_played': 1462749857}
review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the latest and most innovative game in the Shantae series so far. 
There's a lot I could say about this game but I'm just going to list off some Pro's and Con's.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
- Amazing sprite art reminiscent of the 16-bit era
- Brilliant chiptune soundtrack by none other than Jake "Virt" Kaufman (Shovel Knight)
- Gameplay inspired by Castlevania and MegaMan respectively
- Humorous dialogue between characters.

[h1]Con's[/h1] 
- Difficulty ramps up quite suddenly toward the end
- Quite short for the price (Ranging from 10-15 hours)
- Controller is [b]Necessary[/b] for most people
- Lack of actual button prompts (For instance the game will tell you to press the "scimitar button" as opposed to the actual button on your controller/keyboard.

Do I recommend this game? Yes.
Does it have its faults? Sure.
Is it fun? You're god damn right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012205383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1523882681}
review:
[h1]Shantae and the Pirate's Curse[/h1]

(Originally played this title on the Wii U)

Platform: PC Windows
Genre: 2D Sidescroller/Platformer/Metroidvania

[b]Introduction[/b]:

This is now the second game I've ever played where the protagonist is a female with her hair being her main power (The first one being Bayonetta). This installment in the main Shantae series from Way Forward Technology, just like the previous installments, offers much more than whipping your hair back and forth, Willow Smith style. A 2D platformer with a stunning soundtrack, Shantae and the pirate's curse is truly a blast to play and is arguably the best entry in the series.

[b]An uneasy alliance[/b]:

Shantae is a half genie girl, belly dancer, and the guardian of Scuttle Town. Following the events of Shantae: Riskys Revenge, Shantae has now lost her Genie powers, but instead gets to borrow some of her former nemesis Risky Boots weapons to get by. When the mayor of Scuttle town sells the town for some chocolate to the military madman Ammo Baron, Shantae is forced to spring into action. Bigger problems lies at hand though, as Risky Boots confronts Shantae about the impending return of the Pirate Master, an evil tyrant who was sealed away by the genies of Sequin Land long ago. They reluctantly choose to work together and weaken the dark powers across the land by visiting many different islands and defeating evil creatures to prevent the Pirate Masters return.

[b]Hair whipping & dungeon exploration[/b]:

Shantae's pony tail is something to be respected and it will be your main way of taking on the great variety of enemies that you will encounter. Whipping enemies as well as breakable pots makes gems drop which you can then use to upgrade your various items and said hair. Scuttle town acts as the hub town and you return there many times to buy shampoo for her hair, making your attack power go up and a silky cream which allows for faster whipping. A few damage upgrades are also available for new items that you will acquire as you progress through the story.

A 2D platformer with Metroidvania and The Legend of Zelda (Get item in dungeon, use said item on dungeon boss) style gameplay, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is certainly the best game yet in the Shantae series. Now that Shantae doesnt have to perform a dance (Although she is a very talented one) to transform herself into different animals but instead uses Risky Boots weapons and gear to get around, the pacing is a clear step up from previous titles. The dungeons are fun to explore and the platforming, while not being all that difficult, is still one of the best things about Shantae, mostly because of how perfectly precise the controls are. The dungeons also feature some thrilling boss fights at the end of each one, but I was a bit disappointed in the lack of difficulty and challenge most of them provided.

There are also Risky Boots army of small dark creatures called Tinkerbats that have been possessed by the Pirate Master's dark magic that Shantae can find in various locations. You can also find heart squids throughout the game that will increase your overall health. Just like in any Zelda game, trying to find all of these isn't all that compelling, with the somewhat lack of challenge that the game overall provides, but a few tricky platform sections and the latter part of the game will surely cause some unexpected deaths. The game lasted me about 10 hours the first time around and it also features a new game + mode, where you get to keep all your acquired items, but not upgrades and heart containers, and enemies do double damage.


[b]Presentation & Soundtrack[/b]:

The game looks gorgeous in all of its retro glory and is populated with many lovable side characters, witty dialogue and some great 4th wall breaking moments (many of them courtesy of the reoccurring character, the self-proclaimed filler boss Squid Baron), amazing 16 -bit animations and it's the small details that really made me take notice. Shantae, as mentioned previously, is a seductive belly dancer, and sometimes she might start to sway her hips side to side to Jake Kaufman's expertly produced soundtrack. Even when you are crawling on the ground or carrying Rottytops, Shantae's green zombie friend, who just so happens to have a thing for genie brains, Shantae is shaking her behind or stepping to the beat.

The music is upbeat and absolutely brilliant and accompanies each stage perfectly. Jake Kaufman further enforces my strong need for great musical scores in video games because they can really make or break your gaming experience. With Shantae and The Pirates Curse, its top notch and I certainly don't blame her for dancing. 

[b]Verdict[/b]:

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse offers superb animation quality, a downright awesome soundtrack and addicting gameplay that will certainly make you want to come back for more. It might not the best Metroidvania style game out there, but it is one of the most memorable and fun retro style games that i've ever experienced. Her hips don't lie and neither do I, so get this game, you will not regret it.

[b]9/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197994915883', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1505431382}
review:
A huge improvement on the previous outing [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/277890/] [i]Shantae: Risky's Revenge[/i]. [/url]
[i]Shantae and the Pirate's Curse[/i] is a very solid platformer with fun characters, tight controls which rarely let the player down, and amazing music. 
However, the boss dungeons aren't as well designed for backtracking as the main world. I've already had to completely restart after I got stuck searching for items in the 4th dungeon!
Despite this little design oversight, I would still heartily recommend this to anyone who remembers the glory days of 16-bit 2D games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013027885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1451374302}
review:
I LOVE THIS GAME!

After the medicore port of the last game i was kinda worried about playing this one, but MAN it's GREAT.

Like everything about it is something I love, Shantae feels more fluid and faster, the writing is better, the animations are better, the levels are challenging but fair and never seem to over stay their welcome or get me bored, I always have the sense that if I leave something behind i'll be able to get it once I get a new item or something which is great.

If you're on the fence about this game, but you like platformers, silly writing, and just really solid gameplay I would take the dive and get this game, I didn't really play the first two that much but I get the basic gist of the relationships between the characters.

This game gives me faith that the next one will be amazing, and now i can't wait!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982665201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1685960087}
review:
In a nutshell: I really enjoyed this game.

"Shantae and the Pirate's Curse" made me feel like I was back playing my old SNES. For a game made in 2014, it does an excellent job of capturing that classic old platformer feel and gameplay. But the appeal of this game doesn't end with the nostalgia factor. There's some really good humor in this game which makes for a really enjoyable play experience and the puzzles can get a bit tricky; not so much that they become a nuisance, but just enough to make you clever when you figure them out.

The characters were great and had a surprising amount of depth for a game that shows so much cleavage (pun not intended). There's a lot of character development in this game and, especially by the end, I found myself caring more then I would have expected about what happened to them and their relationships with one another. For me, this was one of the game's most endearing qualities.

On the negative side, this game does have it's imperfections, too. I mentioned earlier how this was a very loyal SNES-era style platformer and it is, in both the good ways and the bad. Playing Shantae and the Pirate's Curse reminded me why I would sometimes get so frustrated as a kid that I'd throw my controller at the wall. Things like timed jumps and frustratingly narrow gaps between spike filled walls, when not used properly, can easily become a nuisance which detracts from the enjoyability of a game. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse unfortunately succumbs to this pitfall. Long sequences that relied upon me timing numerous jumps perfectly - under threat of being sent back to the beginning over and over and over until I got it right- were aggrivating and the game would've been much better if they had been made so that you only took damage when you made a mistake, instead of being sent back to the beginning. The final journey to the big-boss was the most notorious culprit here, but there were other areas that suffered from the same problem. Forcing a player to replay long sequences over and over and over is annoyingly repetative and makes for a poor impression of the game as a whole.

Also, while I was able to get my Logitech Precision gamepad to work with this game, it required me to do some serious tweaking with some 3rd party software to get it to work and I was a little disappointed that Shantae and the Pirates Curse didn't include native support for it. "Shantae and the Pirate's Curse" is the kind of game that is really meant to be played with a controller (I briefly tried to play it via keyboard and I found it really awkward and hard on the fingers), so it's a shame there wasn't more effort put in to insuring that the game was more compatible with controllers.

But I won't let these minor frustrations ruin what was overall a really fun game! This game was well worth the money I paid for it and I will be eagerly awaiting it's sequel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002006133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1484823651}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023091943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 862, 'last_played': 1558459126}
review:
After having played Shantae: Risky's Revenge, I had already fallen in love with this series, and Shantae was already one of my 2 favorite video game characters of all time! For a single game to be able to do that speaks volumes about its quality. Now let's take this already flawless platformer and make it even better. What do you get?  You get Shantae and the Pirate's Curse.

HOLY COW!!! This game is incredible! It somehow managed to take everything the previous games did right and perfect it. The game mechanics, from hair whipping to hat parachuting to simple running and walking animations, are very fluid and wildly entertaining to witness. The pace of the game is never too slow because you're always getting new items, which each give the game a new level of depth. The various levels you explore are vibrant and colorful, or dark and forboding if it's a dangerous level, but the tone matches each stage perfectly and helps to draw you into the world. All the characters are incredibly loveable and fun, and the character models themselves are stunningly beautiful from an artistic perspective! The music is also ridiculously catchy!

I have tried, but I honestly CANNOT find a single problem with this game. The developers at WayForward have poured their hearts and souls into this game...and it really shows! As I have said previously on my review of Shantae: Risky's Revenge, this is a series that should absolutely be played. I can personally guarentee that you will not be disappointed if you buy this game, even at full price! Thanks WayForward Games for my favorite Half-Genie!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037633867', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1451113289}
review:
WF组的游戏其实并不陌生，从DS上魂斗罗4，到唐老鸭的妇科，最终这款重新被拿出来的shantae，这个开发团队对于这类复古的横板动作类游戏还是很有心得的，似乎铲子骑士的开发人员很多都是来自于这个开发组。桑塔与诅咒的海盗有着浓厚复古情调的配乐，流畅爽快的手感，轻松又常常出现惊喜的解密，除了较短的流程外，真的没有什么可以说的缺点！

最重要，最最重要的是，女角色很骚，女角色很骚，女角色很骚。不管是屁股扭来扭曲的举着灯，还是像一只小猫一样撅着屁股的匍匐前进，还是和她的几个闺蜜们穿着炸裂的埃及服装，都是满满的骚气！特别是这黑皮裸装乳摇的色气竟然在马赛克里得到了增幅！这种真正的绅士才能看懂的美妙，这帮制作人真的很懂嘛（wu！如果你是塞尔达迷萨姐迷恶魔城遗老，更巧的你竟然还是个绅士，那么你真的没有任何理由错过这款游戏！

期待新作！

author: {'steamid': '76561198074134910', 'num_games_owned': 580, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1643161889}
review:
Don't worry about my playtime, I fully completed the game on 3DS originally, and liked this game so much I had to buy it a second time.  

This is easily one of the best Shantae games yet: great controls, cute character art and vibrant world design, and plenty of collectibles to keep you playing for a while.  

The only possibly negative thing I would mention is something potentially a little divisive.  If Risky's Revenge turned you off from Shantae with it's confusing world design that had you jumping between the foreground and the background to navigate the world, you'll be pleased to know that's gone for a more traditional, and much easier to navigate, single plane.  However, if you liked it, you might be disappointed at the simplification.  

Shantae doesn't have her trademark transformations here, but they more than make up for them with some really fun gadgets that, among other things, let her rocket jump through the air, charge through obstacles, and shoot at faraway switches.  

+Pros
+ Cute art!
+ Catchy background music!
+ Fun platforming!
+ Gadgets mix the gameplay up!

-Cons
- ...*cricket sounds*
